editionStmt.edition: Digitale Ausgabe von 〈Stele des Antef (Strassburg 345 + Florenz 7595)〉 nach den Daten des TLA-Projekts

availability.licence: Metadata and texts are released as Creative Commons, Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 (CC BY-SA 4.0)

support.note: Kalkstein; 54 x ca. 36+x cm (B x H)

origin.origPlace: Qurna Laut Winlock wohl aus et-Tarif. Genauer Fundort unbekannt: Fragment Firenze: 1891-1892 von Schiaparelli in Luxor angekauft (Bosticco, 31); Fragment Strassburg: 1898 in Luxor angekauft (Spiegelberg/Pörtner, 11).

listBibl.bibl: - B. Porter und R.L.B. Moss, Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Texts, Reliefs, and Paintings. I. The Theban Necropolis. Part 2. Karlsruhe, Mülhausen, Strassburg, Stuttgart, Strassburg i. E. 1902, 11-12 (Nr. 18) und Tf. XI (Nr. 18) [P,H,K] (nur Strassburg) - W. Landgrafova, It is My Good Name that You Should Remember, Prague 2011, 2-3 (Nr. 1) [H, Ü]

ab.s: An offering which the king gives and Osiris, lord of Busiris: an invocation offering for the royal seal-bearer and sole friend (of the king), overseer of foreign troops and general, Antef, who says:
I sailed downstream and upstream with a mission of the hereditary noble and local prince, great chief of Upper Egypt Antef, to the place where the rulers of Upper and Lower Egypt were headed.
Every ruler who arrived there, they then rejoiced over meeting me, because my speech was good.
I was one open of mouth, beneficient of counsel and commanding (?) of utterance on the day of assembling, one who gives a statement, [self-controlled on the day of] council, the dignified An[tef].
His beloved wife, the sole ornament of the king, priestess of Hathor, Iru.
